newsitem.title: USA: US crop insurers persuade lawmakers to boost funds.
newsitem.headline: US crop insurers persuade lawmakers to boost funds.

text.p: U.S. crop insurers have persuaded key Senate lawmakers to support funding for agent commissions by about $50 million above the Clinton administration's request.

On Tuesday, the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on agriculture voted to provide $202 million in discretionary funding for agent commissions in fiscal 1998, compared to $188.6 million approved last week by the House Appropriations Committee and $150 million sought by the administration.

The full Senate Appropriations Committee will take up the fiscal 1998 spending bill containing the crop insurance provision on Thursday, which is roughly when the House version of the bill is expected to go to the floor for action.

As part of its negotiations with insurers on coverage for 1998 crop, the U.S. Agriculture Department has sought to reduce the government subsidy for agent commissions to 24.5 percent of annual premiums, from 29 percent this year and 31 percent for 1996 crops.

However, crop insurers pushed for funding at 28 percent of annual premiums--the maximum amount allowed for the 1998 crop by the 1996 farm bill and the level approved Tuesday by the Senate Appropriations subcommittee.

"We do not believe that the (U.S. Agriculture Department) Secretary (Dan Glickman) has a reasonable, rational or evidential basis to make the statement that funding the crop insurance delivery system at only 24.5 percent" is adequate, the crop insurers said in a letter to lawmakers.
Such a cut would lead to fewer companies selling crop insurance, reduced services for farmers and higher loss ratios, the insurers said.
